message_1: A metal cube of density 8000 kg/m³ and dimensions 10 cm x 10 cm x 10 cm is suspended by a thread and submerged in water. What will be the tension in the thread and the apparent weight of the cube? Given the density of water to be 1000 kg/m³ and g= 9.8 m/s².
message_2:
First, we need to find the volume and mass of the cube.

Volume of the cube (V_cube) = length × width × height
V_cube = 0.1 m × 0.1 m × 0.1 m = 0.001 m³

Mass of the cube (m_cube) = density × volume
m_cube = 8000 kg/m³ × 0.001 m³ = 8 kg

Now, we need to find the buoyant force acting on the cube due to the water.

Volume of water displaced (V_water) = V_cube = 0.001 m³

Mass of water displaced (m_water) = density × volume
m_water = 1000 kg/m³ × 0.001 m³ = 1 kg

Buoyant force (F_buoyant) = m_water × g
F_buoyant = 1 kg × 9.8 m/s² = 9.8 N

Next, we need to find the actual weight of the cube.

Weight of the cube (W_cube) = m_cube × g
W_cube = 8 kg × 9.8 m/s² = 78.4 N

Now, we can find the tension in the thread (T_thread) and the apparent weight of the cube (W_apparent).

Tension in the thread (T_thread) = W_cube - F_buoyant
T_thread = 78.4 N - 9.8 N = 68.6 N

The apparent weight of the cube (W_apparent) is the same as the tension in the thread.

W_apparent = T_thread = 68.6 N

So, the tension in the thread is 68.6 N, and the apparent weight of the cube is 68.6 N.
